captions.text:
With all the talk these days about "leaping
years," we should probably be asking "what

is a year, anyway?" Ignoring all cultural
history, a year is basically the period of

time that it takes for one physical body to
orbit another. So an earth month could equally
be called a "moon year."

But to under-simplify things, even if we stay
on earth, there are several different ways

to define a year
— either the time it takes for the tilt

of the earth's axis to come back to the same
angle relative to the sun (called a tropical

year)
— or the amount of time before we come back

and see the same stars rising behind the sun
(called a sidereal year - pronounced like

ethereal)
— or, since the earth follows an elliptical

orbit which precesses, we could measure the
amount of time between closest approaches

to the sun (this is called the anomalistic
year).

Of course, all three "years" have slightly
different lengths. But our day-to-day civil

calendar does its best to follow the tropical
year, since its duration is defined by the

tilt of the earth's axis which also determines
the passage of the seasons.

There are non-earth years, too: Mercury's
year is roughly 88 earth days, Neptune's is

165 earth years, and the "Galactic" year – which
is how long the whole solar system takes to

orbit once around the Milky Way – is around
a quarter of a billion earth years! But not

all galactic years are long: check out this
timelapse of stars orbiting the supermassive

black hole at the center of the Milky Way!
Even though you can't see the black hole,

it's pretty obvious that it's there, what
with all those stars zipping around in orbits

taking only ten earth years! Astrophysicists
have even used these orbits to figure out

that the black hole is as massive as 4 million
suns.

But enough about interstellar timekeeping…
if you want to learn more about leap years

here on Earth, check out Grey's new video
over on his awesome channel, "cgpgrey"

And a big thanks to the UCLA Galactic Center
for doing sweet supermassive black hole research

with the Keck telescope in Hawai'i, and for
sharing their images with the public.

title: What are years... and the galactic supermassive black hole!

comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+electrocat1 All right, so I did a little research and basically it's 
because of something called "black-body radiation".

"Physicists believe that to an outside observer, black holes have a 
non-zero temperature and emit radiation with a nearly perfect black-body 
spectrum, ultimately evaporating. The mechanism for this emission is 
related to vacuum fluctuations in which a virtual pair of particles is 
separated by the gravity of the hole, one member being sucked into the 
hole, and the other being emitted."

Perhaps a star getting is simply brighter because the black hole can't emit 
enough light, heat, whatever shit because it isn't sucking enough in. As we 
saw in the video the "black hole area" was small in comparison to some 
stars orbiting it. Perhaps the black hole is in a phase where it is 
gobbling up the last of a previous star but hasn't began to munch on any 
new ones yet. So the stuff in the star is getting excited causing it to 
become brighter while the black hole is running out of fuel?

Only a theory, I'm not completely sure.
comments.author: Hardik Shrestha

comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
Sorry, I didn't understand your question the first time.

My guess on why it looks brighter than some other stars would be that there 
are a few stars getting sucked in and compressed into a very tight space. 
As long as light can escape the black hole, we will see stars burning 
brighter, combine that with the fact there are probably more than a few 
stars being sucked in, and we get the small bright "circle" around a black 
hole. 

This is just my guess and I would appreciate it if you prove me wrong ;)

comments.author: BlazePlayz

comments.text:
Yes black holes, like all massed objects, are affected by gravity.  The reason that the object even happens to be a black hole is because it has mass, just quite a lot of it in one place.  They're incredibly dense.  The way gravity works is that it "bends" the fabric of space-time, like a ball on a stretched-out piece of cloth.  Therefore, even massless objects, like photons, which aren't technically supposed to be affected by gravity, but they are, will bend around an object with a lot of mass.  If you look towards a black hole, you will see parts of the space behind it smeared all around the edges of what you're looking at.  This effect is apparent around any spheroidal object, however the intensity is proportional to the average density of the object.

Also, Ask is not a Q/A site, it's just a search engine, like Google.  If you're looking for answers for simple questions, try ChaCha.  WolframAlpha also helps, but it is not very good at answering direct questions; it is better at manipulating and analyzing data, as well as mathematical things.  People who don't want malware on their computers don't use Ask, and they don't let the Java installer install Ask Toolbar.

comments.text:
A meter is defined as the distance light travels in 1/299,792,458 seconds. 
A centimeter is 1/100 that. It never changes because light travels at a 
constant speed in a vacuum.

comments.text:
The Earth spins and moves elliptically around the Sun. The Sun itself 
wobbles up and down much like a sine wave. The Sun and its respective 
planetary constituents move around the center of our Milky Way galaxy. Our 
galaxy is constantly moving around within a local group which is called the 
Virgo cluster. The Virgo cluster itself is speeding away from everything 
else. Speed is truly relative.

comments.text:
+Kalle Jillheden I think I should mention that black holes are very 
powerful. It takes no less than another black hole to get it to orbit. 
Everything else will simply orbit the black hole.

This is a lot like if you were in a tug of war contest with a car. You both 
pull on the rope but really, who is going to win? Even if you had 20+ big 
men helping you, the car is going to be difficult to beat. The rope in this 
instance is gravity which keeps orbiting objects bound.

The car can be pulled though. Either by a bigger car/truck, or in this 
case, a bigger black hole. Does this do better to answer your question?
comments.author: Clymaxx

comments.text: +John Smith Minute physics; go! ;)
comments.author: Kalle Jillheden

comments.text:
+Kalle Jillheden No, we were being sarcastic. a superMASSIVE black hole has 
a super amount of mass. Two black holes can indeed orbit each other. You 
can get a whole slew of amazing phenomenon caused by black holes affecting 
different celestial bodies. Quasars, pulsars, large beautiful accretion 
disks from destroyed stars, spiral galaxies... They're worth reading up on.
Side Note: Pretty much everything tangible has mass, but light does not, as 
you said in another comment. The formula E=mc^2 can be represented as a 
right angle triangle. If an object is travelling at the speed of light, it 
is physically impossible for it to have mass according to traditional 
physics. It instead is 100% energy. This is hard to explain through 
a youtube comment...

comments.text:
Psychology. Take a multiple choice test. You see an question, and know the 
awnser, because you've learned your theory. As soon as you see the right 
awnser, you get and impulse to choose it, which you do, without really 
thinking. But then, you read the question again, and the impulse you had 
first when you read the right awnser, is gone. Then, you try to take an 
awnser that sounds logical, but isn't the awnser you chose before. But 
since your first awnser was right, you'd always be wrong.
comments.author: JustTheDutchGirl

comments.text:
The reason why we second guess ourselves is because of additional 
information. First we make a decision based on a set of evidence. Then 
after we made our decision we continue to think about the possibility that 
another answer would be preferable. You think about the possible ways the 
other answer is better and then that possibility creates doubt in your 
original answer. The more you think about the other answer being better, 
the more you doubt your first answer.

eventually collapse into a singularity is the same as being a black hole.

seasons.

comments.text:
You should do a video on months and moon cycles. There are 13 cycles in a 
year. There are 7 days in a week, 4 weeks in a month. and 12 months in a 
year. So each month has more than 4 weeks(28 days). Those extra days add up 
to 30. So another month which would make it 13 months in a year. Not sure 
if13 being unlucky have anything to do with it, but heard12 was used to 
stop use of moon calendars and change to catholic season calendar which is 
easier to divide Better for north than equatorial life
comments.author: lcbreezyl
